Sorry Juan, but the very last sentence you said, IMHO, is not that correct.=


One thing is the REST badge =3D Complaint of all constrains.
Another one =
is the quality of the system/service. If you have components that do not pl=
ay by the rules, you loose what the rules were intended for, and thus the q=
uality of service suffers. If the service is good or bad, well used or not,=
 that impacts the system somehow. So, a misbehaving client should be taken =
seriously into account, even if it doesn't take your badge away. 

To me, t=
he REST certificate is useless beyond marketing and selling points. It will=
 not give much if the architecture is not controlled and governed as it sho=
uld.

Finally, and to be fair that is my line of thinking "out of the bun",=
 I have a presentation of a talk I gave at the SOA and Cloud Symposium, Bra=
zil, where I explained why a RESTful service may come with a little of impe=
dance mismatch, and as such is not suitable for many business cases. In tha=
t sense, the service may have its implementation in perfect REST, with a pe=
rfect client, and still the quality may be poor.

Maybe the main point here=
 is not the badge thing, but agreeing that there are concerns that are deep=
er and far more important that the actual badge itself. What do you think?
=

William.
